newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy gives state railway year's tax grace.
newsitem.headline: Italy gives state railway year's tax grace.

text.p: The Italian Treasury said on Thursday it was giving the state railway a year's grace to repay 3.0 trillion lire in taxes dating from 1992-95.
It said in a statement it had taken the decision at the request of the railway, which had argued the measure was needed to safeguard jobs and guarantee essential public services.
The Treasury, the only shareholder in the state railway, said the levy would be payed back gradually and would have a neutral impact on Italy's public sector borrowing requirement.
It said the decision was perfectly in line with practices approved by Eurostat, the group of European Union Statiticians.
In February this year, Eurostat approved the Italian government's public deficit accounting practices.

The Italian government has been under pressure to upgrade the country's archaic rail network, which was hit by a series of accidents earlier this month. In the space of four days, a train jumped the tracks in Rome, a crane working to remove it collapsed onto tracks and another train ploughed into a car on a level-crossing, killing three people.
The accidents prompted calls for the resignation of Transport Minister Claudio Burlando, who responded by appealing to his government for more funds.
